title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
text:
THE Essex County Courthouse in Newark has the dubious distinction of having two criminal trials of major political figures going on at the same time. Last Monday, on the fifth floor of the courthouse, the trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and his co-defendant, former City Council President Earl Harris, on charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office got under way with jury selection.
At the same time, but on the eighth floor, pretrial arguments on the admissibility of recordings of telephone conversations were being heard in the case of State Senator John T. Gregorio. The 56-year-old lawmaker, who also has been Mayor of Linden since 1967, is charged with conspiracy, tax evasion, tampering with records and misconduct in connection with two go-go bars in Linden in which he is alleged to have had a hidden interest.
In an 11-count indictment, Mr. Gregorio is accused of splitting $64,000 in income from the bars with the manager of the establishments.
New Jersey Journal highlights various brief news stories concerningNew Jersey
The trials have generated a good deal of interest, with that of Mayor Gibson and Mr. Harris far overshadowing that of Senator Gregorio.
Mr. Gregorio is the fourth Democratic State Senator in less than two years to face trial. Former Senators Angelo J.Errichetti of Camden, David J.Friedland of Jersey City and William V.Musto of Union City were convicted in separate trials in Federal courts.
The presence of television cameras in both courtrooms during the current trials has been approved. The Gibson-Harris trial is expected to last about six weeks, the Gregorio trial more than two months.
Mayor Gibson and Mr. Harris are accused of knowingly and illegally permitting Michael A.Bontempo, a former Newark City Councilman, to collect more than $115,000 in salary over a seven-year period while serving as head of security for the city's 35,000-acre Pequannock Watershed. The facility is the source of Newark's drinking water.
Specifically, Mr. Gibson and Mr. Harris are accused of having created a job for Mr. Bontempo and allowing him to collect a salary even though he allegedly did little, if any, work. Mr. Bontempo, who is a co-defendant in the case but whose trial was severed because of his failing health, is 81 years old. He allegedly lived in Port St.  Lucie, Fla., during part of the time that he was on the city payroll.
Disclosure of the position came to light during a news conference called by Mayor Gibson to assess progress on repairs to the city's 22-mile aqueduct, which was crippled when vandals caused the 36-inch pipes to be undermined and rupture. The trial of the four youths accused of the vandalism is scheduled to start tomorrow.
The arduous task of selecting a jury to hear the charges against the 50-year-old, four-time Mayor and the 62-year-old former Council President was complicated by the judge's questioning each prospective juror in his chambers. The judge, Paul R. Huot, normally sits in Bergen County, but was assigned to this case by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court.
Jurors were asked a series of 69 questions, ranging from whether they knew any of the participants in the case to whether they had any bias or prejudice concerning government, politicians, officials or employees of government that would prevent them from fairly, impartially and objectively evaluating the evidence.
The prospective jurors also were shown a list of more than 200 present and former government officials who might be called as witnesses. The list included Representatives Peter W. Rodino Jr. and Millicent Fenwick, as well as private citizens and business leaders.
The death of two men in a mid-air collision of two single-engine planes over Essex County Airport in Fairfield three weeks ago brought to five the number of fatalities resulting from crashes of light planes in the state this year. However, it is a marked decrease from the number of such fatalities that have occurred in recent years.
For instance, in 1981, 15 persons were killed in six of 79 lightaircraft accidents that year; in 1980, 25 persons were killed in 10 of 68 crashes.
Thus far this year, according to figures compiled by the state's Division of Aeronautics, an arm of the Department of Transportation, there have been 39 crashes of light aircraft. Among them was a fatal incident on Aug. 15, when a single-engine Beechcraft crashed into a grove of trees near Mercer County Airport, killing the three persons aboard.
Aeronautics officials credit safety programs instituted by the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board with the reduction in crashes and fatalities.
In the Essex County Airport incident, the collision - it involved a four-seat Cessna 172 and a two-seat Cessna 150 - occurred while one of the men who died in the crash was undergoing one of the safety procedures, a biennial review of his flying ability.
According to government officials, the man, Haynesley Thomas, 40, of Brooklyn, was being checked out by Carlos Rodriguez, 27, a flight instructor from Passaic. The two men had taken off from Teterboro Airport and were given clearance to conduct ''touch and go'' takeoffs and landings at Essex County Airport.
Both died when their plane collided with one being flown by Mario Diaz, 32, of Irvington, who also had been given clearance to conduct similar landings and takeoffs.
An investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board said that the plane carrying Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Thomas was slightly off course at the time, and had been warned of an impending collision a split second before contact.
The American Automobile Association has stepped up its campaign opposing legislation that would allow larger trucks on New Jersey highways. It has sent to every member of the Legislature a copy of a nine-page brochure put out by the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, which is calling for lifting the 55-foot limit on overall truck length and favors allowing 60-foot tractor-semitrailers and 65-foot twin trailer combinations on the highways.
The brochure calls attention to the economic benefits of raising the limits to conform with those of contiguous states. However, the A.A.A. says that the use of such rigs would pose a danger to motorists on New Jersey's already congested highways.
ODDS & ENDS: Oral arguments are expected to begin this week in the appeal by former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., who was convicted of various charges stemming from the Abscam investigation. Mr.  Williams, who has appealed to the Second District Court of Appeals in Manhattan, resigned from the Senate last spring as it was considering moves for his ouster. He had been in the Senate for 23 years. … The Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Newark will be the scene of a series of 16 concerts featuring music from around the world. The series will begin at 3:30 P.M. today with an organ recital by Richard Morris, a former parish priest who started his performing career at the age of 12 with the Atlanta Pops Orchestra … More than 200 cultural groups and historic organizations will take part in the exhibits, displays and performances at the Bergen County Arts Festival at Bergen County Community College in Paramus on Oct. 3. The shows will include ballet, bagpipes, orchestras and barbershop quartets … A citywide symposium on the impact of an elected Board of Education for Newark will be held at Essex County Community College in Newark on Oct. 23. Last May, the city's residents voted overwhelming to have an elected board rather than one appointed by the Mayor.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
text:
EIGHT teen-agers from New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Florida are attempting to do what no one has ever done before: Make a trip around the entire perimeter of New Jersey all under their own power.
The Jersey Journey, as it is called, was organized by Project U.S.E., a Long Branch-based group that provides wilderness experience for urban youths and others normally excluded from the challenges of the outdoors.
According to Phillip M. Costello, a Project U.S.E. founder, the teen-agers started on the first leg of the journey - a 70-mile hike along the Appalachian Trail - last Sunday. They are not expected to return to the starting point, the group's Wilderness Center on Wildcat Mountain in Passaic County, until Aug. 17.
From the Delaware Water Gap, where the first week's hike ends, the youngsters will take to canoes for a 185-mile voyage down the Delaware River, stopping at Penn's Landing in Philadelphia and making a one-day excursion to, and tour of, the nuclear-power generating station in Lower Alloways Creek, Salem County. The plant is owned by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.
New Jersey Journal discusses several news stories from New Jersey
''The kids have a campsite right at the station, and they can practically canoe into the power plant,'' Mr. Costello said.  Continuing down Delaware Bay and around Cape May, the group will then travel up New Jersey's Atlantic coast, putting in some time sailing, canoeing, hiking and biking. The final leg of the journey will be a two-day bicycle trip back to Wildcat Mountain for work on Project U.S.E.'s new log building.
''This is New Jersey's version of a Mount Everest expedition,'' Mr. Costello said.  Aside from the challenge of doing something that has never been attempted before, Mr. Costello explained that the reason for the trip was to give the youngsters a ''real good look at the diverse environment of New Jersey and to focus on some of the current environmental problems in the state.''
''We also wanted to show them that they don't have to go to Wyoming to have an adventure,'' he added. ''They can have it right here.''
As of June 28, the terms of all seven state appointees to the 15-member Pinelands Commission had expired, leaving the commissioners in holdover positions until Governor Kean decides whether to reappoint or replace them. (Of the eight other commissioners, seven are county appointees and the last is named by the United States Secretary of the Interior.)
Some of the commissioners have been holdovers for as long as two years. Others, like Floyd V. West, the Mayor of Bass River Township, and Gary Patterson of Woodland Township, served three-year terms that expired last month.
Published articles in several newspapers have indicated that the Kean administration wants to replace Mr. West and Mr. Patterson, two of the strongest environmentalist voices on the panel. One other commissioner, Peter J. Burke of Williamstown, has asked not to be reappointed because business commitments have prevented him from attending many commission meetings.
The names most often mentioned as potential replacements are Steven Pollock, a planner for Ocean County; Elwood Jarmer, a planner for Cape May County, and Stephen Lee of Chatsworth, a berry grower.
Environmentalists have reacted vehemently to word of the replacements. As Carol Barrett, chairman of the West Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, put it:
''To lose Mr. West and Mr. Patterson is not only to lose the most knowledgeable and visible environmentalists on the commission, but it gives a sign that the Governor has said, 'O.K. boys, we won't support weakening pinelands protections through legislation, but we will support doing it administratively.' ''
Mr. West and Mr. Patterson have long been involved in pinelands issues. Mr. Patterson, who has fought to save the area for 13 years and served as vice chairman of the original Pinelands Review Committee, said that he would remain actively involved in pinelands issues even if he was not reappointed.
''The greatest solace I can take if three nonenvironmentallysensitive appointees are placed on the commission is that it will take them a while to undo the environmentally good work that Floyd and I have done,'' Mr. Patterson said.
Franklin E. Parker, the first and only chairman of the commission, has told Governor Kean that he wants to continue in that position, despite indications last year that he wanted to step down because commission members were placing too great a demand on his time as a corporate attorney in New York City.
''We haven't progressed as rapidly as I had wanted to on getting towns to conform to the management plan,'' Mr. Parker said. ''I want to be much more comfortable with that before I leave.''
Paul G. Wolcott, a spokesman for the Governor's office, said that an announcement on the appointments should come within a week.  ''There really has been no final decision so far,'' he said.  ''There have been rumors that two of the commissioners may be replaced. Well, they may be - but, then again, they may not be.''
The NJ Transit bus garage in Union City, which was partly destroyed by fire in May, still does not have a roof over Bay G, the last of seven bays in the busy Bergenline Avenue facility.
City officials said that NJ Transit, the state's mass-transit agency, had promised that it would hire a contractor and start repairs on the turn-of-the-century trolley barn-turned-bus garage within a short time of the fire. The officials were worried about the safety of the structure after the fire. Now, however, they have new concerns.
NJ Transit has announced plans to build a $25 million transportation center and garage in Secaucus. Despite that, Anthony L. Grazioso, a spokesman for NJ Transit, said that the agency was soliciting bids for repair work on the Union City facility.
''We're discussing plans to build a number of new garages around the state,'' Mr. Grazioso said. ''We have included the Secaucus facility in projections of our capital projects; if we get the money for it, we will build the new garage in the Meadowlands there. The fire at the Union City garage has moved up the project in our preliminary planning.''
Local officials in Union City were annoyed when they learned of NJ Transit's plan through a third party, not because it meant that the two-square-block garage in the city's commercial district would be abandoned, but because NJ Transit did not notify the city accordingly.
''When an agency has been married to a city that long, it would have been nice for somebody to call and say that we're thinking about moving,'' Robert C. Botti, Union City's Commissioner of Public Works, said.
According to Mr. Botti, the city now receives between $85,000 and $90,000 a year in lieu of taxes on the property.  ''I'm not concerned about NJ Transit moving out,'' Mr. Botti said, ''because I'm confident that we can develop the property to bring more dollars into the city.''
The area is zoned for commercial use, and Union City officials would like to see it developed into a large office complex. The approach to the Lincoln Tunnel is a block away.
If the skies over New Jersey had not cracked open with lateafternoon showers last Monday, all three New Jersey-based electric utilities would likely have set peak-load records that day.
After a weekend of scorching temperatures, people returned to sweltering offices and factories on Monday and, naturally, turned on the air-conditioners. That vast load, combined with an increased residential load, pushed demand up to an almost record-breaking pace throughout the day.
By mid-afternoon, officials of Public Service Electric and Gas, the state's largest utility, were projecting a new peak load for the system. Priscilla E. Suber, a spokesman for Public Service, said that the company anticipated sending out 7,250 megawatts between 5 and 6 P.M., which would have topped the previous record of 7,159 megawatts on July 21, 1980, when the temperature soared to a blistering 102 degrees.
However, the old record remains intact. Late-afternoon showers brought down the temperature and allowed some fans and airconditioners to be shut off. The highest demand for electricity came at 3 P.M., just before the showers. At that time, Public Service was sending out 7,035 megwatts of power.
According to Miss Suber, the utility had all of its generating stations operating, including both nuclear units, and easily met the demand.
The Jersey Central Power and Light Company also reached its peak load at about 3 P.M., when it sent out 2,894 megawatts. The utility's previous record, also set on July 21, 1980, was 3,024 megawatts.
New Jersey's third electric utility came closest to setting a record. Atlantic City Electric reported a peak demand of 1,254 megawatts at 6 P.M., just 10 megawatts lower than the record 1,264 megawatts that it sent out last July 9.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
text:
THE Newark Boys Choir School, which for the last decade and a half has trained hundreds of youngsters for the internationally acclaimed Newark Boys Choir, will move next door to the city's Symphony Hall in the fall.
The move is expected to allow the school, which has had serious financial difficulties, to continue to provide many low-income, inner-city boys 9 to 13 years old with a comprehensive educational and cultural experience. The school is currently at 505 Orange Street.
''The business community really came through,'' said Robert J.  Edelman, general manager for planning and development of the Western Electric Company and president of the school's board of trustees, ''Now, instead of worrying about closing our doors, we can look forward to a much brighter future. We have improved our financial position substantially, and the move to Symphony Hall will create a center of culture right there on Broad Street.''
New Jersey Journal highlights news of importance to New Jersey residents
The school, which has an annual budget of about $280,000, was begun in 1969. Its financial woes last year were attributed to rising operating costs, a reduction in government aid for the arts and the faltering economic climate that evaporated some financial support.
The Newark Boys Chorus, which is composed of 26 of the moreadvanced youngsters at the school -the rest are in the training chorus - has won national and international acclaim. It recently presented a successful concert at Carnegie Hall, and in 1973, accompanied by the Italian Radio Symphony under Leonard Bernstein, it sang at the 10th anniversary celebration of Pope Paul. Last year, it won kudos on a three-week tour of Japan.
Concerts, which bring in about $60,000 a year, have been booked well in advance, with a fall tour of southern colleges coming up.  In addition to training in music theory and singing, the 53 boys in grades 5 to 8 get individual instruction in academic courses.  ''The individualized nature of the program allows the youngsters to push themselves to their limit,'' said Lawrence R. Emery, assistant academic director at the school, who also teaches science, history and English. ''The result is that many are two and three years ahead of their grade level in reading comprehension and math skills.  Private schools in the area want our youngsters.''
Because of the small number of students at the school, the per pupil cost is about $6,000. Tuition is $750 a year.
The isolation and academic pressure that may lead high school freshmen to drugs, alcohol or both are being countered in two Princeton schools by group interaction led by upper classmen.
At a conference next Saturday, the schools -Princeton Day School and Princeton High School -plan to demonstrate the skills needed for such a preventive program. The conference will be held at the Princeton Day School, and at least 100 students, teachers and counselors from schools in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut - some of which run programs similar to Princeton's peer adolescent groups - are expected to attend.
The Princeton programs, created and directed by Sharon Powell, offer freshmen a way to meet people and discuss problems with drugs, alcohol and relationships. Seniors trained in group dynamics lead the discussions and activities.
Peer group pressure is popular at both schools. At Princeton High, 180 of about 250 freshmen chose peer groups over a faculty adviser.  Many students said they joined to meet people. Beth Berman, a senior, said she learned that she was not alone in experiencing certain problems.
Ralph Heyman, a Princeton High teacher, said he had noticed a change in the school climate since the program began four years ago.  ''The social life is a little more fluid,'' he said. ''Students see they can have fun and activities where there's no alcohol.''
With an aim toward heading off the adoption of a bill that would require 5 percent deposits on all beverage containers, the New Jersey Food Council has begun a program designed to make consumers more aware of grocery items that come in boxes made of recycled newspapers.
More than 50 supermarkets, including some of the largest chains across the state, are pinpointing eggs, pasta, detergents, pet foods and other items that are packaged in recycled materials.
The move makes New Jersey the first state in the nation with a statewide packaging awareness program, according to Barbara W.  McConnell, executive director of the Food Council. She said that this was part of a nationwide consumer-education effort focusing on the benefits of using recycled packaging materials.
''This is the first time that an entire industry has participated in an effort of this kind,'' Mrs. McConnell said. ''All the major chains are involved.''
Mrs. McConnell, a former Democratic Assemblywoman from Flemington, said that, although only 50 stores were targeted for the initial phase of the drive, more than 90 percent of the approximately 1,050 supermarkets and grocery stores in the state carried items in recycled packages. Recycled paper is also used to make the bags in which groceries are carried home.
Mrs. McConnell noted that old newspapers and waste-paper products made up about 34 percent of all the waste materials dumped in landfills, many of which are nearing capacity. She said that New Jersey had a comprehensive recycling program, and that 286 of the 576 communities in the state had some form of newspaper- and glasscollection programs.
According to Mrs. McConnell, New Jersey has set a goal of recycling about 25 percent of all newspapers sold in the state and 50 percent of all glass.
''The food industry is committed to helping the state meet these goals,'' she said. ''Our aim is to make the state's system work effectively. The food industry is very much opposed to a bottle bill because it would only deal with beverage containers.
''Programs in other states that deal only with beverage containers are not working. Recycling is a comprehensive program, and is a better way of dealing with all wastes.''
Assemblyman Thomas H. Paterniti, Democrat of Metuchen, who has sponsored the bill requiring a 5-cent deposit on all glass, plastic and metal beverage containers, said that his proposal would deal effectively with one of the major problems in the state: litter and broken glass.
''I have been receiving a lot of calls from environmental groups supporting my bill,'' he said. ''It has been released from committee, but I don't know if it will come up for a vote this year. The Assembly Speaker (Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville) said he wants to see a report on how the state's recycling law is working.''
Assemblyman Paterniti, who is also a dentist, said that his proposal did away with many of the complaints from union groups that requiring deposits would eliminate jobs. The bottles, cans and plastic containers would be crushed and not be reusable, and the materials would then be recycled.
''No particular industry would be adversely affected,'' Mr.  Paterniti said. ''The plan would generate extra money for the state and could even create jobs.''
Starting tomorrow, Amtrak riders headed for Washington will be able to board express Metroliners at Pennsylvania Station in Newark.  The Newark stop, according to Amtrak officials, will save passengers 15 minutes and 50 cents from the normal $45 New York-to-Washington fare.
The express, at 2 hours 49 minutes Amtrak's fastest rail link to the nation's capital from New York, was introduced two years ago with limited stops along the way, said Diane Elliott, an Amtrak spokeswoman.
''Originally, the New York-to-Washington run stopped only in Philadelphia and Baltimore,'' she said. ''Because of rider requests, we added Wilmington, Del., last year.''
Similar requests and complaints, Miss Elliott added, prompted Amtrak officials to study the Newark stop, particularly because of the city's easy access to Wall Street.
''It's much easier for people from the financial district to take a PATH train to Newark and catch the express there than get the same train out of Penn Station in New York,'' she said.
ODDS & ENDS: Perth Amboy High School will hold a Decathlon of Knowledge next Saturday, a series of events that will pit 10-member teams from the 20 high schools in Middlesex County in tests of knowledge and intellectual skills. … Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark has urged President Reagan to unconditionally pardon Frank Wills, a former security guard at the Watergate complex in Washington, who was arrested and sentenced to a year in jail for stealing a $12 pair of sneakers for his son. Mr. Wills was instrumental in discovering a burglary being committed at the Democratic Party's headquarters at Watergate, the incident that eventually led to President Richard M. Nixon's resignation.

text:
ton, six-story structure that draws 25,000 tourists to Margate each summer, is wearing thin and is about to be reconditioned, thanks to a local preservation group.
''There's a whole lot of work to be done, both on the outside and in,'' said Josephine Harron, head of the Save Lucy Committee, a nonprofit group of 30 volunteers. The state is providing loans of $4,000 for exterior work and $48,000 for interior renovations.
Since its formation in 1973, the committee has raised $360,000 to keep Lucy in shape, Mrs. Harron said. ''Lucy's a one-of-a-kind,'' she added, explaining that among the attraction's many honors was a ''landmark'' designation bestowed by the National Historic Society.
New Jersey Journal column highlights efforts to save Margate landmark, Newark Public Library and New Jersey Senatorial campaign
Built in 1881 by a local land developer who wanted to emphasize the ''wilds'' of undeveloped terrain, the structure served as a realestate office. In 1970, Lucy was donated to the city of Margate and moved to a public beach area three blocks south, thus giving her greater visibility. The transfer cost $9,000.
''We couldn't see Lucy being torn down back then to make way for a new high-rise,'' Mrs. Harron said. ''She is just too unique to have had such an end.''
Lucy's design plans are patented and still on file in Washington.  When the renovations are completed, she will serve as a small museum of seashore history.
''We're hoping for additional interest and funds from the county,'' said Mrs. Harron, explaining that Atlantic County Freeholders have been verbally but not financially supportive of Lucy in the past.
The Newark Public Library has cut its staff by one-third because of reductions in state aid. According to Anthony Vacca, a spokesman for the library, 89 of 271 librarians, custodians, pages and administrative staff members were let go. Also, 31 current employees will be demoted in a move designed to eliminate raises.
''In addition to that, we lost 10 people over the summer through attrition, and they will not be replaced,'' Mr. Vacca said.  Hours at the main library on Washington Street will not be affected, but library administrators plan to reduce them - some by as much as 50 percent -at 10 branches throughout the city, as well as at two community libraries based in the Dayton Street and Mount Vernon elementary schools. They also plan to close the music and education departments in the evening and curtail, from three days a week to one, access to the New Jersey reference section.
Mr. Vacca said that this year's state aid, totaling $661,000, was a reduction of 19.6 percent from last year's $822,000.  Library administrators also hope to curb some spending by introducing a security system designed to prevent book thefts in an inventory that boasts 1.2 million volumes. However, the system will not be in operation for some time.
Although the Newark City Council has increased its aid to the library by as much as 50 percent in recent years - the total budget for 1982 is $4,264,000 -state aid is expected to continue to drop.
''The city has pretty much held up its end,'' Mr. Vacca said.  ''However, with Reaganomics and the recession, it looks very bleak for the next year.''
Library administrators have been seeking donations from businessmen but say that funds have not surfaced because there is no corporate representation on the institution's Board of Trustees. Board members are appointed by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson.
''I suppose that business people in the community feel that, if they are going to donate money to the system, they should have a say in how the money is spent,'' Mr. Vacca said.
The New Jersey State Safety Council reports that the number of traffic fatalities in the state's 21 counties has dropped by 14.5 percent - from 792 in the year ending Sept. 5, 1981, to 677 through the same 1982 date.
The decline, said William C. Peto, director of the council's Traffic Division, is a result of the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit and increasing safety awareness among drivers.
Addressing a recent meeting of the Bergen County Traffic Safety Committee, Mr. Peto said that most fatal accidents were caused by drunken drivers. One way to help reduce the fatality rate, he said, would be a legislative agreement between New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania to raise the minimum drinking age to 21. The drinking age is now 19 in New York and New Jersey and 21 in Pennsylvania.
''With this type of mutual legislation,'' Mr. Peto said, ''the number of accidents in which lives are wasted will drop drastically because it will deter people from crossing state lines to purchase liquor.''
He stressed that a high percentage of drivers involved in fatal accidents were 16 to 24 years old.  According to the council, of the 677 fatalities reported in the 12-month period ended Sept. 5, a total of 246 occured in 225 accidents on state highways, 275 in 149 accidents on county roads and 105 in 94 accidents on municipal streets.
The Trojans, a team of eight paratroopers from Fort Devens, Mass., are scheduled to drop into Palmer Stadium Saturday during half-time of Princeton-Army football game, The contest marks the first time since 1940 that Princeton will be playing Army at home.
Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former Secretary of State, who has been lecturing at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public Adminstration, is expected to be in the stands. So is Gen. John R. Guthrie (ret.), a member of the Princeton Class of 1942, whose son, Kevin, is an end on the Princeton team, and Lieut. Gen. Willard W. Scott Jr., superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point.
The state board of the New Jersey chapter of the National Organization for Women, representing 9,000 members, has voted to support Frank Lautenberg, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator.
''We regret that we cannot support Millicent Fenwick,'' said Christine Carmody-Arey, NOW's New Jersey coordinator. ''I am an affirmative action person, and I want to see more women in the House and Senate. But we insist on qualified people who have a record that we can support. Unfortunately, Millicent Fenwick fails to meet our criteria.''
According to NOW, Mrs. Fenwick voted to support President Reagan's economic policies 64 percent of the time.  ''Millicent Fenwick is a proven supporter of E.R.A.,'' said Mrs.  Carmody-Arey, ''but she votes against economic programs designed to benefit women, particularly working women and their families. She voted to cut back on day care, Medicare, housing, food stamps, nutrition programs and job training for women entering the work force. She also voted against a guaranteed minimum of $122 a month in Social Security benefits.''
Assemblywoman Angela L. Perun, Democrat of Plainfield, agreed.  ''Fenwick voted for budget cuts which result in the impoverization of females and children,'' she said. ''Much of our families are single-parent families with women at the head. It is the mother who is getting kicked in the teeth.''
''The bottom line is economics,'' Mrs. Carmody-Arey said. ''When Fenwick says that she supports women's issues, and then votes for the closing of five of the nine New Jersey day-care centers, votes to eliminate 90,000 New Jersey children from school lunch programs and votes to reduce Medicaid benefits and nutrition programs for the elderly, then she is talking out of both sides of her mouth. My Irish mother calls that 'blarney.' ''
''She is a nice person,'' said Nancy Stultz, staff member of the New Jersey NOW office. ''But we need someone who is going to help us. We cannot afford Millicent Fenwick.''
Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado and a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, will speak on ''The Future of Arms Control'' at the third annual Teaching Conference on Nuclear Disarmament at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton Saturday and next Sunday.
The conference is sponsored by the 700-member Coalition for Nuclear Disarmament, coordinated by the Rev. Robert Moore, a United Church of Christ minister. The coalition, which includes 21 Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish organizations, seeks to foster alternative systems of national security and promote peace by political action and education.
Other scheduled speakers at the conference are Joseph Lowery, president of the United Christian Leadership Conference; Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, Washington; William W. Winpinsinger, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers; Inga Thorson, Swedish Under Secretary of State; Mark Garrison, director of the Center for Foreign Policy Development, Providence, R.I., and Herbert Scoville Jr., president of the Arms Control Association, Washington.
Workshops will be held on such topics as nuclear ''numbing,'' lobbying skills and the medical implications of nuclear weapons.  There also will be plays, readings and dances by local artists. An interfaith worship service will be held Sunday in the Princeton University Chapel.

text:
A raid by Federal agents on a Passaic clothing factory earlier this month may force the deportation of 40 illegal Polish aliens, all of them women who worked as sewing-machine operators. The raid, which was conducted by 50 agents of the Internal Revenue and Immigration and Naturalization Services, centered on Fashion Associates Inc.
The company's financial records were also seized under warrants issued by United States Magistrate G. Donald Haneke in Newark for what officials are calling probable violations of Federal income tax, labor and immigration laws.
Of the 52 persons arrested, all but one were released within hours of being interviewed at the Immigration Service office in Newark.  ''One woman, a Filipino national, is still being held,'' said Diane Armenakis, an assistant United States Attorney. The 40 women, she said, are considered illegal aliens and face deportation proceedings, but no criminal charges. However, because of political unrest in Poland, officials stress that deportation is unlikely.
New Jersey Journal highlights illegal aliens in Passaic, hospital course on how to cope in a medical emergency and drop in burglaries in Morris County
''From what I understand, for these women to remain in the country legally, they must be classified as 'political exiles' by the State Department in Washington,'' Mrs. Armenakis said. ''That's where the issue stands right now.''
The women are believed to live in the Wallington and Passaic areas, which have large Polish-American communities.  Mass arrests of illegal aliens in New Jersey are not unusual. In April, several hundred Colombian and Salvadoran nationals were seized in one week throughout the state and eventually deported.
A special program originating from Overlook Hospital in Summit is getting across the message that keeping calm and avoiding panic are just as important in saving lives as cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, as it is commonly known.
''Emergency: The First Five Minutes!'' is a two-hour course taught by certified members of the hospital's CPR Unit on how to cope and what to do in a medical emergency. The program has just been completed by 150 employees of Bloomingdale's at the Short Hills Mall, and additional classes are expected to resume after the holidays.
''There's such a helpless feeling in people who witness someone who collapses,'' said Connie Anderson, the hospital's CPR coordinator, adding that training focuses on what to do in the interim. ''For the most part, when there's an accident or someone is stricken, there isn't a doctor in the house.''
Mrs. Anderson said that immediate help could be offered by trained co-workers or employees. Action in those few minutes between the time someone is hurt and an emergency medical unit arrives can often save lives.
''Mainly, we're teaching people to keep their heads and call for immediate assistance,'' Mrs. Anderson said. ''A medical unit that's properly informed on the situation by a caller who calmly describes the emergency has a better chance to do its job.''
The program, which took a year to plan and organize, is serving businesses and industry in parts of Union, Morris, Essex and Somerset Counties. Hospital officials contend that demand for the training will increase once the course is better known.
''The employees in Bloomingdale's were enthusiastic over the course and quick to pick up on it,'' Mrs. Anderson said.  The course costs $40 per instructor for each 10 students.
Dr. William Pecoraro of Demarest has won a legal battle, and its effect is not so much on his wallet as on his eardrums. For the last 12 years, Dr. Pecoraro, a dentist, has objected to a high-pitch fire siren that is bolted to a utility pole just outside his home and office on Hardenburgh Avenue.
His pleas to local officials for its removal, Dr. Pecoraro contends, have fallen on deaf ears. But the State Superior Court has ruled that the siren is a public nuisance and has asked the Demarest Mayor and Council to seek a solution.
The siren, like its counterpart across town, is the only practical way to alert the volunteer firefighters, emergency officials say.  They will not remove the sirens, but have curtailed a testing schedule and lowered the sound level.
''The problem is that the siren goes off at all hours of the night - and not just in emergencies,'' Dr. Pecoraro said, adding that residents in 180 towns throughout the state have similar problems.  Local and state health officials have documented that the siren, which blares for nearly three minutes, exceeds Federal standards in terms of noise level.
''Sometimes, it goes off a few times in the middle of the night, and sometimes in the day, when I'm working on a patient,'' Dr.  Pecoraro said. ''You learn to make do.''
If town officials continue dragging their heels over the issue, Dr. Pecoraro said, he and several neighbors will continue legal action.  ''This is more than a little peace of mind for me,'' he said. ''I'm trying to protect my family and our hearing.''
Of the nearly 10,000 vehicles pulled over and examined in October by roving inspection teams of the state's Division of Motor Vehicles, more than half failed because of one or more safety defects.
Clifford W. Snedeker, the division's director, said that the drivers of 31 percent of those vehicles were given tickets for extremely serious safety violations. The tickets were written by local police officers aiding the inspection teams.
Also, 165 cars were impounded because they were ''too unsafe for continued highway operation,'' were unregistered or were being driven by motorists with suspended licenses.
Since September, when the roadside spot inspections began, nearly 15,000 private and commercial vehicles have been stopped. The inspections are limited to off-peak hours so as not to cause motorists delays in their work schedules.
The average inspection is said to take about five minutes.
Psyching out the opponent is the name of the game these days for Dr. Selwyn Mirkin, a Teaneck psychologist with a doctorate in human relations. He treats athletes, mostly tennis players and the like, who have a problem in common: They can't win.
Dr. Mirkin described his technique, which he calls ''See-Feel-Win,'' this way: ''I determine if the person is susceptible to being put in a trance state first. If he is, I hypnotize him and let him regress to a time in a previous match when he felt comfortable and played well.
''Then we run through a match that may be upcoming and which he's nervous about. I have him imagine making excellent strokes and trouncing his opponent. Actually, I'm desensitizing my client to think positive.''
The patient, he said, must meet two criteria if treatment is to be worthwhile: He must have had successful experiences in the past and he must be susceptible to hypnosis.
Dr. Mirkin said that he could, for example, bring an ex-Ping Pong player who had not competed in 10 years up to 80 percent of his former capacity.
One of the psychologist's patients is 12-year-old Henry Mandeville of Montvale, who is ranked 15th in his division by the Eastern Tennis Association. Henry has been undergoing treatment for five weeks.
''It's unbelievable,'' his mother said. ''Henry played a 17-yearold top Bergen County teen-ager -I mean he shaves already - and he made a good showing. Last weekend, a kid who Henry had never beaten before just folded under my son.''
A 94 percent increase in burglaries in Morris County between 1975 and 1980 prompted County Prosecutor investigators there to come up with an educational crime-prevention program and resource center financed by a $36,000 Federal grant.
Since January 1981, more than 125 municipal police personnel and thousands of citizens have cooperated to reduce residential and commercial burglaries, which went from 3,315 in 1981 to 2,202 in the first eight months of this year, a decrease of 33.6 percent.
The Society of Crime Prevention Practictioners - a national organization of law-enforcement professionals - sent its president, Brooks Russell of Seattle, to Morristown earlier this month to give the county the society's Outstanding Unit award for ''contributions, accomplishments and achievements in this exciting new field of public safety.''
John T. Dempsey, Morris County's crime-prevention coordinator, attributed much of the success to citizens trained by the police in neighborhood seminars. He noted that 60 percent of the burglaries occurred in the daytime, and that residents' new awareness and new precautions had helped neighborhoods to make themselves less vulnerable to intruders.
''Municipal Police Departments with manpower shortages were willing to risk taking a man off patrol duty to institute crimeprevention programs, and now they can see the benefits,'' Mr.  Dempsey said. ''Citizens in 38 municipalities have become the eyes and ears of the police to direct them to places where crimes may be about to occur.''

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 19, 1983
text:
International
Syria rebuffed President Reagan, rejecting his appeal to withdraw its forces from Lebanon and announcing it would not receive an American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, to discuss the issue. The Syrians also hinted they might close their entire border with Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 3.)
Margaret Thatcher opened her drive for re-election as Prime Minister, announcing a Conservative Party program that she pledged would improve living standards and enhance Britain's stability. The program calls for further curbs on the power of trade unions and the removal of one layer of local government. (A3:1-3.)
Summary of major news stories in May 19 New York TimesThe deaths of two left-wing Peronists were called assassinations carried out by the Argentine military authorities in an intensifying drive to intimidate opposition political leaders. The accusations were made by opposition leaders and human rights activists in separate statements. (A1:5-6.)
Temple Fielding died of a heart attack at his home in Palma, Majorca, at the age of 69. The distinguished travel books by the Bronx-born writer charted the way to Europe for millions of American tourists.  (D26:1-2.)
National
A major immigration bill was passed in the Senate by a vote of 76 to 18. The comprehensive measure would outlaw the hiring of illegal aliens and authorize an amnesty for more than one million illegal aliens already in this country. The bill now goes to the House, where a similar measure is awaiting a floor vote. The Reagan Administration generally supports the legislation. (A1:6.)
A proposed Federal budget with large deficits and only minor tax increases was approved by Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee and sent to the Senate floor. The unexpected action signaled a second attempt by the Republican majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., to muster enough votes for a budget acceptable to President Reagan. The Senate defeated a similar plan last week. (A1:4-5.)
Rita M. Lavelle was cited for contempt of Congress by the House for failing to comply with a subpoena to testify before a House investigations subcommittee. Miss Lavelle is the former head of toxic waste programs for the Environmental Protection Agency. Meanwhile, William D. Ruckleshaus was sworn in as the new Administrator of the agency. (A1:1.)
W. Wilson Goode moved quickly to consolidate his commanding positon after winning the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Philadelphia. In one of the largest turnouts in the city's history, Mr. Goode, a black sharecropper's son, defeated former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo by more than 7 percentage points. (A18:1-2.)
William H. McNichols Jr., the dominant figure in Denver politics for 14 years, has lost his bid for a fourth term as Mayor. Mr. McNichols, who is 73 years old, finished a distant third in a field of seven candidates in Tuesday's primary. The two top vote getters must face one another in a runoff June 21. (A18:3-5.)
U.S. submarines are training widely under the Arctic ice to be ready in wartime to attack nuclear-armed Soviet submarines that have increased operations there, according to the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James D. Watkins. He differed with Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. over another strategy, saying that aircraft carriers should not enter waters near the Soviet Union in a war, as advocated by Mr. Lehman. (A17:1-3.)
House members were not implicated in a drug investigation undertaken by the Capitol Police Force, but the force's investigation contained irregularities, according to a report on a House inquiry conducted by Joseph A. Califano Jr. (A19:1.)
The new chief of the U.A.W. is Owen F. Bieber. He was elected without opposition as the sixth president of the United Automobile Workers by about 2,500 delegates attending the union's convention in Dallas. Mr. Bieber, who has been a vice president of the embattled, 1.1-million-member union, will succeed Douglas A. Fraser, 66, who is retiring because of a U.A.W. rule barring anyone over 65 from seeking union office. (B15:1-2.)
Metropolitan
A deadline on emergency plans for the Indian Point nuclear plants cannot be met, according to Federal and New York State officials.  They said that problems with emergency plans for the Lower Hudson Valley plants could not be solved by the June 9 deadline set by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, but they added that enough progress might be made by then to persuade the commission to allow continued operation. (A1:1-2.)
Dumping of hazardous waste in ''massive quantities'' in New York City landfills was cited in a study by a research group. The group said the study had documented the widespread dumping, which was legal at the time and was authorized by city officials. The city's Sanitation Department said tests by the Health Department had found no danger.  (B3:1.)
The Met's raffle drive valued a gem at $60,000. But Ann Cicchelli, who won the yellow sapphire as the top prize in the opera company's 1982 fund-raising raffle, said that six appraisers had valued it at no more than $7,000. She began legal action against the Met after the opera company informed the Internal Revenue Service that the prize was worth $60,000. (A1:2-4.)

title: NEXT MOVE ON A POSSIBLE DEFECTOR IS UP TO WASHINGTON, OFFICIALS SAY
text:
A State Department official here said today that a Chinese diplomatic courier had asked for asylum, but the Immigration and Naturalization Service would not confirm that such a request had been made, and officials here said that officials in Washington must make the next move in the case.
The courier, Gogiang Yang, remained in Chicago under the joint authority of the service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Mr. Yang was aboard a Pan Am flight from San Francisco to New York when it made an unscheduled stop Friday at O'Hare Airport in Chicago and he left the plane. He had had an in-flight dispute with a fellow courier, airline officials and passengers said, and he gave a diplomatic pouch handcuffed to his wrist to the other courier before being taken into custody by F.B.I. and I.N.S. officials.
State Department official says Chinese diplomatic courier asked for asylum, but Immigration and Naturalization Service refuses to confirm this; courier, Gogiang Yang, remains in Chicago under joint authority of service and FBI (M)
Today, Peter Galuppo, the special agent in charge of the State Department's office of security here, said Mr. Yang had asked for asylum, but he could not confirm that the necessary papers had been signed.

'Totally Confidential'
However, A. D. Moyer, the district director of the immigration service here, would not say that Mr. Yang had made an official request to remain in the United States.
''Asylum requests are such that the nature of them are totally confidential unless the party requesting asylum chooses to go before the public,'' said Mr. Moyer, whose agency is responsible for making decisions on requests for asylum.
The courier is still classified by the State Department as a diplomatic official accredited by a foreign government, Mr. Moyer said, and until that classification is changed, ''I am not going to interfere.''
Mr. Galuppo, the local State Department official, said, ''It is now being taken care of at the White House, which is considering the case, and the Chinese Embassy will be involved.''

Further Consideration Expected
''There will be a lot of political in- house things going on from this point,'' Mr. Galuppo said. ''There'll be a couple of days of settling down. My experience in the past is that this is not a quick type of thing.''
The chief F.B.I. agent here, Edward D. Hegarty, would say only that the bureau ''has been interviewing Gogiang Yang, People's Republic of China courier, since Friday, Nov. 25, 1983, which is within the jurisdictional purview of this agency. No additional comment is being made at this time.''
Decisions on asylum are made by the immigration service, but that agency generally seeks and follows the advice of the State Department.

title: NIGERIAN REFUGEES' AFRICAN HELPERS
text:
To the Editor:
Prof. Martin Kilson's Feb. 9 letter charging Nigeria with ''moral myopia'' in the expulsion from Nigeria of illegal immigrants and your editorial condemnation of Nigeria to which he referred both reveal an inability to make moral distinctions.
How can one compare a system whose laws deny all freedom of movement to the vast majority of citizens (South Africa) or one which tortures political prisoners (Zaire) or one which aggressively advances religious fanaticism (Libya) with the legal expulsion of foreigners who came into the country on 90-day visits and long overstayed? We in Africa do not live in the best of all possible worlds, any more than Americans faced with illegal Mexican, Haitian and Cuban immigration do.
As a former Nigerian Foreign Minister and, like Kilson, a black intellectual, I do not hesitate to make moral judgments where appropriate, whatever the offenders' race, but I must protest when emotions interfere with reasoned analysis.
J.N. GARBA, Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 23, 1983

title: OVERHAUL OF IMMIGRATION LAW GAINS IN SENATE
text:
The Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a bill to overhaul the nation's immigration law in a major step toward resolving a long-term dispute.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was the lone dissenter Thursday as the panel voted, 16 to 1, to send the proposal to the Senate.
Just minutes before the final vote, Mr. Kennedy won a concession that would greatly increase the number of illegal aliens now in the country who would be eligible for legal status.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) - The Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a bill to overhaul the nation's immigration law in a major step toward resolving a long-term dispute.
The Republican-controlled committee, by an 8-to-7 vote, approved Mr. Kennedy's proposal to give temporary legal status to illegal aliens who could prove they had been here since Jan. 1.
Another version had set the date at Jan. 1, 1980, the same as in a similar immigration bill pending before the House Judiciary Committee.
The difference of two years could mean legal status for five million illegal immigrants, or 500,000 more aliens than would otherwise be eligible, according to Reagan Administration and committee figures. It is estimated that there are six million illegal aliens in the United States.
Temporary legal status would be the first step for an illegal alien to gain citizenship. However, some illegal aliens say they are fearful of stepping forward and acknowledging their illegal status.
Administration officials said that if Congress agreed on the 1982 date, President Reagan would probably accept it. The Administration had recommended Jan. 1, 1981, as the cut-off date.
The bill also proposed permanent legal residence for any immigrant here before Jan. 1, 1978.

Penalties Against Employers
The measure would also impose the first civil and criminal penalties against employers who knowingly hired immigrants who lacked legal status.
Mr. Kennedy objected to that provision. He said he was worried that employers, out of fear of being fined and sentenced to jail, would automatically reject job applications from people of Hispanic descent.
Mr. Kennedy had unsuccessfully proposed that such sanctions against employers be automatically canceled after two years unless the President could certify that they were not being used to discriminate against members of minority groups.
In recent years attempts to change the immigration law have stalled in Congress as proposals got caught between opposition from many sides. Hispanic groups, among others, favored eased restrictions on immigrants, while opponents pushed for stricter measures to guard the nation's borders.
The committee vote on Thursday suggested that Congress might be ready after years of stalemate to overhaul the immigration laws.  Bipartisan praise was showered on Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, the sponsor of the measure, for working out a painstaking compromise. The House version, which is close to the Simpson bill but not exactly the same, is sponsored by Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky.
Both measures contain the proposed sanctions against employers. An employer would be required to check a job applicant's eligibility by asking him to show either a birth certificate or passport and a Social Security card or driver's license.
The legislation envisions that after three years the Government would develop a means of checking legal status, through an identification card or through a computerized data bank.

title: PATROL SEARCHES HARDER AS MEXICANS SEEK EASIER LIFE IN U.S.
byline: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times
text:
Jorge Castro waited for his chance here on the cement bank of the Rio Grande, in the shadow of downtown El Paso, Tex. He waited warily for the right moment to evade detection by American border agents and make a dash for the United States.
Mr. Castro said he was trying to get to a regular job as a painter and handyman that he had recently started in El Paso.  ''It's getting very hard in Juarez,'' he said in Spanish. ''I was working in a plant here. I was paid very little for a lot of work.'' In June the plant laid him off and he began considering seeking work on the other side.
Border Patrol reports increase in number of Mexicans illegally entering US
''The devaluation made up my mind,'' he said. ''I went over on a Sunday, got a job on Monday.''

Rise in Arrests
Officials of the Border Patrol, a law-enforcement arm of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, say more Mexicans are attempting entry in the El Paso region, which stretches 180 miles along Texas and New Mexico west to the Arizona state line. Alan E.  Eliason, chief patrol agent for the district, estimated that the total of arrests of undocumented aliens for August would show ''a 25 percent to 30 percent increase'' over the same month last year, when 12,430 were arrested.
Border officials say they believe the reasons for the increase are the Mexican Treasury's Aug. 5 devaluation of the peso, which has fallen in value from 49 to the American dollar to 126, and the start of the harvest season, when seasonal workers, many of them in the United States illegally, are used by American agricultural businesses to bring in the cotton, fruit and vegetable crops.
''We think the largest percent of the increase is due to the peso devaluation, because July was rather comparable to last year,'' Mr.  Eliason said.
Local Mexican-American groups and others suggested that the rising number of arrests also reflected a crackdown intended to put pressure on Congress as it considers tough new immigration legislation.

Some Cross Daily
Mr. Eliason said he supported the legislation, now at a critical stage of consideration by Congress, but he called suggestions that the increased arrests were politically motivated ''absolutely ridiculous.''
''We are faced with increased illegal entries, we tried to put more people on the line to apprehend illegal entries, and we arrested a larger number than usual because there are increased illegal entries,'' he said.
Last week the El Paso district reported that on Aug. 24 it broke a one-day record by arresting 1,205 Mexicans for illegal entry into the United States. The average number of daily arrests for the month of August so far is 452, in contrast to 401 in August last year.
''As long as there's that lure, jobs, we're not going to be able to do anything about it,'' Mr. Eliason said.

Urges Tougher Legislation
State Representative Paul C. Moreno, an El Paso Democrat who is chairman of the Mexican-American Legislative Caucus in the Texas House of Representatives, said he believed the Border Patrol's announcement of record arrests was timed to aid the measure.
''That's the way politics is done, the way bills are passed,'' Mr.  Moreno said. ''I have no doubt that's the reason.'' ''We've had the Border Patrol for years,'' said Joe Loya, director for El Paso of the League of United Latin American Citizens. ''Why, all of a sudden, are they being so effective?''

Supported by Administration
The immigration measure is sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky. It would, among other things, require employers to seek proof of citizenship or legal alien status from all prospective workers, and by extension would require job applicants to have such proof available.
Critics of the legislation assert that it would discriminate against Americans of Hispanic descent because, in practice, they say, only Hispanic people would be asked for proof.
The measure, which is strongly backed by the Reagan Administration, also calls for fines of as much as $2,000 and jail terms for employers who regularly employ illegal workers. The House Judiciary Committee is scheduled to consider it on Sept. 14.
Mexican-American leaders such as Mr. Loya said that the legislation, if passed, would not stem the flow of undocumented aliens from Mexico because economic conditions here were so bad.
Mr. Castro, who has a wife and a daughter, said he now pays 15 pesos for a kilo of tortillas that cost 7 before the devaluation this month. He said the American dollars he brings home help him to cope with the higher prices.

Blending Into the Streets
But even on that point there is disagreement. Another man, Jose Luis Hernandez, said he had ''to pay in dollars in Juarez already,'' eliminating any advantage. As he spoke, Mr. Hernandez had already reached the American side of the river and was waiting to blend with the people on El Paso's streets.
Unlike Mr. Castro, Mr. Hernandez has long made a practice of slipping past border patrols to work in El Paso. So has Olga Martinez Robles, an 18-year-old from the interior of Chihuahua State who waited in a group with Mr. Hernandez. She said she has done housework in El Paso homes since the age of 12. ''They pay me the same'' as before devaluation, she said, ''but it's worth a little more.''
Mr. Hernandez said that for four years he has done plumbing work in the United States, for $4.50 an hour, cash.  ''Clearly in Mexico,'' he said, ''1,000 pesos is worth nothing.''

title: SENATE COMPLETES DEBATE ON ALIENS MEASURE
byline: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times
text:
The Senate today completed debate on a bill granting amnesty to millions of illegal aliens and establishing criminal penalties for employers who make a practice of hiring illegal aliens.
A final vote on passage of the bill is scheduled for Tuesday. Both supporters and opponents of the measure say it is likely to win approval from the Senate. A similar measure is pending before the House Judiciary Committee, where its prospects are uncertain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 - The Senate today completed debate on a bill granting amnesty to millions of illegal aliens and establishing criminal penalties for employers who make a practice of hiring illegal aliens.
The Reagan Administration generally supports the bill, having proposed similar legislation last year.  The Senate debated more than a dozen amendments today, but refused to make any substantial change in the basic bill, sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming.

Opposed by Hispanic Groups
Hispanic groups bitterly criticized the proposed amnesty program, saying it was so restrictive that few illegal aliens would come forward to take advantage of it.
The program would grant permanent resident status to illegal aliens who entered the United States before Jan. 1, 1977, and have resided here continuously since then. It would grant ''temporary resident'' status to those who entered the country from Jan. 1, 1977, to Jan. 1, 1980. Temporary residents, after three years in that status, could become permanent residents. Aliens, in turn, after five years as permanent residents, could apply for citizenship.
Antonia Hernandez of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund said in an interview that the amnesty program ''legalized exploitation'' and predicted that ''no one will come forward'' to participate in it.
In a statement released by her organization, Miss Hernandez said: ''The Senate ignored the concerns of the Hispanic community in this bill. The legalization program requires that newly legalized aliens continue to pay Federal taxes without receiving benefits for three years or six years. This is known as taxation without representation.''

Ineligible for U.S. Aid
During their three years as temporary residents and during their first three years as permanent residents, aliens would be ineligible to receive welfare, food stamps, Medicaid and other forms of Federal assistance.
The Senate also authorized an unspecified amount of Federal aid for state and local governments that incur additional expenses as a result of the influx of illegal aliens.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican who proposed the grants to state and local governments, estimated that they would cost $5.5 billion over the next seven years.
Miss Hernandez said that under the proposed amnesty program, illegal aliens who came to the United States after Jan. 1, 1980, would ''continue to live in the same underclass this bill was designed to eradicate.''

Legalization Plan Defended
Senator Grassley estimated that a million illegal aliens had entered this country in the last two years, and said he did not want to legalize their presence here because they had not built up the same ''equities'' as other aliens who had lived here longer.
Senator Simpson defended the legalization procedure, saying that the resources of the Immigration and Naturalization Service were better spent in trying to prevent illegal entries than in trying to locate illegal aliens who had already settled here.
The Simpson bill makes alien workers more readily available to farmers and growers of various fruit and vegetable crops. By a vote of 62 to 28, the Senate today rejected an amendment offered by Senator Edward M. Kennedy that would have required the Government to retain all the existing rules for the temporary worker program.
The Massachusetts Democrat said that it was inappropriate to relax the rules for alien workers at a time of high unemployment in the United States. Under the Simpson bill, Mr. Kennedy said, ''a grower can turn down a U.S. citizen seeking more than the minimum wage,'' and instead hire an alien at the minimum wage.
The Senate rejected, by a vote of 69 to 22, another Kennedy amendment that would have ended the ''employer sanctions'' program after three years if it led to discrimination against Hispanic Americans or other members of minority groups. The amendment would have required the President to certify that the program was not being used in a discriminatory manner.
Under the program, employers must ask all job applicants to demonstrate that they are either citizens or aliens authorized to work in the United States. Employers who knowingly hired illegal aliens would be subject to penalties of $1,000 for each illegal alien on the first offense and $2,000 for each alien on subsequent violations. A ''pattern or practice'' of hiring illegal aliens would be a crime, and upon conviction, an employer could be sentenced to six months in prison and required to pay an additional fine of $1,000.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS REVISIONS IN IMMIGRATION LAW
text:
The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a bill that would revise the nation's immigration laws by establishing penalties for employing illegal aliens and by offering amnesty to more than a million illegal aliens already in the United States.
By a vote of 13 to 4, the committee recommended passage of the bill by the full Senate, which is expected to take up the legislation later this month or next month.
The bill, sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, is similar to one passed by the full Senate last year, 80 to 19.  But that bill died in the House, which was unable to complete action before adjournment. However, this Congress is acting much more swiftly on the legislation than the last Congress did.
WASHINGTON, April 19 - The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a bill that would revise the nation's immigration laws by establishing penalties for employing illegal aliens and by offering amnesty to more than a million illegal aliens already in the United States.
Under the Simpson bill, an employer who hired illegal aliens would be subject to a fine of $1,000 for each alien involved in the first offense and $2,000 for each alien in the second offense. An employer found to have engaged in a ''pattern or practice'' of such hiring could be fined up to $1,000 and imprisoned for up to six months.

Kennedy Amendments Rejected
Before approving the measure today, the Senate Judiciary Committee rejected a series of amendments that would have made the bill more palatable to Hispanic Americans and civil liberties advocates.
The amendments would have liberalized the amnesty for illegal aliens, preserved additional levels of judicial review in immigration cases and ended the ''employer sanctions'' after five years if there proved to be a pattern of discrimination against United States citizens who were members of a particular ethnic group. The amendments were all offered by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
The Simpson bill offers legal status to aliens who have ''resided continuously in the United States in an unlawful status'' since Jan.  1, 1980. Senator Kennedy, using statistics supplied by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said this section of the bill might provide legal status to 1.8 million of the estimated six million illegal aliens.
The committee rejected Mr. Kennedy's proposal to change the eligibility date to Dec. 31, 1981. Under this proposal, he said, a total of 3.6 million illegal aliens might have qualified.
Sixteen months after the last Congress convened, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a comprehensive immigration bill. But the pace is much faster this year, with today's action coming only three and a half months after the start of the current Congress.

House Panel Acted Earlier
On April 6, the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration approved an immigration bill sponsored by Representative Romano L.  Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky. Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, the Judiciary Committee chairman, said today, ''The full House Judiciary Committee will take up the immigration bill some time in May.''
Mr. Rodino said that he would not wait for action by the full Senate as he did last year.  There are several differences between the Simpson and Mazzoli bills. But supporters of the legislation said they were sure they could iron out differences if the two houses passed generally similar bills.
John Shattuck of the American Civil Liberties Union said: ''The committee's action today is a serious blow to the right of political asylum.'' We will make all efforts to change the bill on the Senate floor.'' Mr. Shattuck said his group was ''also very concerned about the discriminatory potential of employer sanctions.''
Antonia Hernandez of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund said the latest version of Mr. Simpson's bill was ''just as objectionable'' as the one passed by the Senate last year.  ''It does not represent the interests of the Hispanic community, which is just as much a part of this society as business, labor and agricultural growers, whose concerns are reflected in the bill,'' she said.

title: SOCIETY MAKES NO-INTEREST LOANS TO NEW YORK'S IMMIGRANTS
text:
On a December evening in 1892, 11 men met at the Wilner Synagogue on Henry Street in Manhattan and pooled their savings - $95 - to establish a free loan society similar to those they had known in their native eastern European countries.
''They would lend out $5 to the next guy off the boat so he could load up a pushcart, make a few dollars to feed his family and slowly pay back the loan,'' said Nathan Belth, executive director of the Hebrew Free Loan Society. The loans were interest free, as the Old Testament prescribes.
The first year the society lent $1,205 in amounts of $5 and $10. By 1905, some 15,000 families, mostly Jewish immigrants living on the Lower East Side, had borrowed $364,480.
Hebrew Free Loan Society, founded in 1892, continues to make no-interest loans to New York's immigrantsLoans of $2 Million a Year
Today the society is still making interest-free loans to immigrants, giving out $2 million each year since 1976. Although the society still lends the majority of its money to Jews, it has been a nonsectarian organization since its founding.
The maximum loan of $750 is given to about 2,500 people each year.  ''Often the loan is for an elderly person whose Social Security check is late or when a family has a sudden crisis like a large medical expense or a business problem,'' Mr. Belth said. ''We don't ask the reason but by the time they leave, we know what it is. The story just pours out. People feel they have to justify their request.
''One woman needed to make the last installment on her daughter's cello. A first-rate one costs $10,000. We've helped a number of musicians.''
The loans must be repaid in 10 months, 10 percent each month. They require a guarantee by a credit-worthy endorser.  On the 75th anniversary of the society in 1967, it reported that it had made loans totaling more than $52 million to more than 776,500 people. Since then the society has lent more than an additional $30 million.
Mr. Belth said that the rate of repayment was high. The society figures, he said, that last year all but $100 in loans were repaid, and those who did not pay them back were probably older people who had died.
Among the donors who had helped finance the efforts of the society was Jacob H. Schiff, a banker, who contributed $100 a few months after the society was formed. In 1896, Mr. Schiff sent his second contribution, $1,000. For the next four years, he contributed $5,000 annually. During his lifetime and that of his son, Mortimer, the Schiffs contributed well over $100,000.
Baron Maurice and Baroness Clara de Hirsch, neither of whom had ever been to the United States, donated $6,000 to the society in 1897. The deHirsches had been organizers of free-loan societies in London, Paris, Cracow, Bucharest and other European cities. In addition, Mr. Belth said, over the years the society has received both small and substantial contributions from those to whom it had made loans.

Referred by Organizations
Few people walk in off the street to the society's office at 205 East 42d Street. Most people hear about the society through community and welfare organizations, including Catholic and Protestant missions and schools and universities.
Small, personal loans are still the society's main concern, but recently it has started some other projects.  In the early 1970's, it started a program of making three-year loans for up to $3,500 to members of the Lubavitcher community in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, who wanted to use the money as part of the down payment on their homes so they could maintain their base in the community. Mr. Belth said the society had made $380,000 in loans to 105 people for down payments. No money has been lost in the program, he said.
Another project provides loans for education in Jewish day schools. Last year, the society began a program of offering loans for college students.
